prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO J2-1 z~1 LIRG
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO J2-1 line measurements of IR bright galaxies at z=0.8-1.1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For the 9 galaxies at z~0.82 - 1.0667, we will obtain CO J4-3 and J2-1 whenever these two lines are accessible in Band 3, 4 and 6. This results in Band 3 observations for CO J2-1 for 4 galaxies at z~1.012 - 1.0667, Band 4 observation for CO J2-1 for 1 galaxy at z=0.82, and Band 6 observations for all 9 galaxies at z=0.82 - 1.0667. For 4 galaxies at z=0.86 - 0.96, their CO J2-1 line falls into the gap between Band 3 and 4, not accessible. We request a total of 6.8 hours. The expected CO fluxes are estimated as follows. Our 9 targets have extensive data from Spitzer 3-160micron photometry and deep PACS photometry at 70 and 160micron. These far-IR photometry provides the full IR SEDs and IR luminosity measurements. To crudely estimate the expected CO fluxes, we adopt one assumption: L(fir0)-L'(CO) relation for local ULIRGs (Solomon \&\ van den Boute 2005), Log10[L(fir)] = 1.7*Log10[L'(CO)]-5.0. This relation gives less bright and more conservative estimates of CO fluxes than if assuming a local spiral galaxy relation of Log10[L(fir)] = 1.31*Log10[L'(CO)-1.37 (Daddi et al. 2010). Because a small number of observed L(fir) to L'(CO) ratios have a large scatter, and it is difficult to be sure which relation to use, but for conservative estimate, we adopt the ULIRG relation. The above equations give CO J1-0 line flux estimates.
There are many uncertainties when computing CO J2-1 and J4-3 brightness based on CO J1-0 fluxes. There is not much published data in the literature to characterize the CO line ratio distributions at z~1. If assuming fully thermalized distributions, J2-1 (J4-3) to J1-0 ratio is proportional to frequency to the power of 2, so CO J2-1 and J4-3 lines can be as much as factors of 4 and 16 brighter than J1-0. However, this is probably the most optimistic case. As shown in Figure 2(b) in the main proposal, CO J2-1 and J4-3 are likely to be brighter than J1-0 by factors of a few, even as much as 10. These are unknown for our targets and are our science goals. Therefore, our estimated CO J2-1 and J4-3 fluxes shown in Table 1 are assumed to be flux(2-1) = 2*flux(1-0), flux(4-3)=3*flux(1-0). The full range could be in a factor of (1-4) and (1-16)J1-0 line fluxes. Since this proposal is designed as a detection experiment, the requested $rms$ is 0.8mJy for both J2-1 and J4-3 lines over the 50km/s width. This will give SNR per velocity channel of 50km/s of (3-5), and the total SNR for the line >=(6-10). The more likely SNR values are $>$(10-20) with the more realistic ratios of J2-1/J1-0 and J4-3/J1-0.
Our proposed program is primarily spectroscopy. Our targets are distant galaxies. They tend to be small and are within the primary beam. We will not need to do mosaic in order to map out the targets. We will have enough SNR to make channel maps. But more realistic cases may give SNR > 10-20, enough detection signals for making channels maps for some sources. We will make image maps for both spectral lines as well as continuum, but we do not require mosaics, no offset pointings and do not need complicated imaging reconstruction algorithms.
We will use TDM (Time Division Mode) because our targets can be observed with low resolution wideband continuum observations. Dual polarizations are adopted. The baseband width is taken as 2GHz with 31.25MHz resolution. For the 5 targets with CO J2-1 observations, we have set 3 sky frequencies in three basebands in order to get additional continuum measurements. Assuming blackbody distributions, we can estimate 1mm and 3mm continua fluxes from observed Herschel photometry. The estimated continuum fluxes are in the range of (0.24-3)mJy at 1mm and (10-77)uJy at 3mm. We expect we should be able to detect these continuum values from our data. None detections of continuum will set the minimum constraints on the far-IR SEDs.

For the 9 galaxies at z~0.82 - 1.0667, we will obtain CO J4-3 and J2-1 whenever these two lines are accessible in Band 3, 4 and 6. This results in Band 3 observations for CO J2-1 for 4 galaxies at z~1.012 - 1.0667, Band 4 observation for CO J2-1 for 1 galaxy at z=0.82, and Band 6 observations for all 9 galaxies at z=0.82 - 1.0667. For 4 galaxies at z=0.86 - 0.96, their CO J2-1 line falls into the gap between Band 3 and 4, not accessible. We request a total of 6.8 hours. The expected CO fluxes are estimated as follows. Our 9 targets have extensive data from Spitzer 3-160micron photometry and deep PACS photometry at 70 and 160micron. These far-IR photometry provides the full IR SEDs and IR luminosity measurements. The above equations give CO J1-0 line flux estimates.
There are many uncertainties when computing CO J2-1 and J4-3 brightness based on CO J1-0 fluxes. If assuming fully thermalized distributions, J2-1 (J4-3) to J1-0 ratio is proportional to frequency to the power of 2, so CO J2-1 and J4-3 lines can be as much as factors of 4 and 16 brighter than J1-0. Since this proposal is designed as a detection experiment, the requested $rms$ is 0.8mJy for both J2-1 and J4-3 lines over the 50km/s width. The more likely SNR values are $>$(10-20) with the more realistic ratios of J2-1/J1-0 and J4-3/J1-0.
Our proposed program is primarily spectroscopy. Our targets are distant galaxies. They tend to be small and are within the primary beam. We will have enough SNR to make channel maps. But more realistic cases may give SNR$>$10-20, enough detection signals for making channels maps for some sources. We will make image maps for both spectral lines as well as continuum, but we do not require mosaics, no offset pointings and do not need complicated imaging reconstruction algorithms.
We will use TDM (Time Division Mode) because our targets can be observed with low resolution wideband continuum observations. Dual polarizations are adopted. The baseband width is taken as 2GHz with 31.25MHz resolution. For the 5 targets with CO J2-1 observations, we have set 3 sky frequencies in three basebands in order to get additional continuum measurements. Assuming blackbody distributions, we can estimate 1mm and 3mm continua fluxes from observed Herschel photometry. The estimated continuum fluxes are in the range of (0.24-3)mJy at 1mm and (10-77)uJy at 3mm. We expect we should be able to detect these continuum values from our data. None detections of continuum will set the minimum constraints on the far-IR SEDs.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: CO J4-3 z~1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO J4-3 observations for 4 targets at z=1

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText:
For the 9 galaxies at z~0.82 - 1.0667, we will obtain CO J4-3 and J2-1 whenever these two lines are accessible in Band 3, 4 and 6. This results in Band 3 observations for CO J2-1 for 4 galaxies at z~1.012 - 1.0667, Band 4 observation for CO J2-1 for 1 galaxy at z=0.82, and Band 6 observations for all 9 galaxies at z=0.82 - 1.0667. For 4 galaxies at z=0.86 - 0.96, their CO J2-1 line falls into the gap between Band 3 and 4, not accessible. We request a total of 6.8 hours. The expected CO fluxes are estimated as follows. Our 9 targets have extensive data from Spitzer 3-160micron photometry and deep PACS photometry at 70 and 160micron. These far-IR photometry provides the full IR SEDs and IR luminosity measurements. To crudely estimate the expected CO fluxes, we adopt one assumption: L(fir0)-L'(CO) relation for local ULIRGs (Solomon & van den Boute 2005), Log10[L(fir)] = 1.7*Log10[L'(CO)]-5.0. This relation gives less bright and more conservative estimates of CO fluxes than if assuming a local spiral galaxy relation of Log10[L(fir)] = 1.31*Log10[L'(CO)-1.37 (Daddi et al. 2010). Because a small number of observed L(fir) to L'(CO) ratios have a large scatter, and it is difficult to be sure which relation to use, but for conservative estimate, we adopt the ULIRG relation. The above equations give CO J1-0 line flux estimates.
There are many uncertainties when computing CO J2-1 and J4-3 brightness based on CO J1-0 fluxes. For the 9 galaxies at z~0.82 - 1.0667, we will obtain CO J4-3 and J2-1 whenever these two lines are accessible in Band 3, 4 and 6. Our 9 targets have extensive data from Spitzer 3-160micron photometry and deep PACS photometry at 70 and 160micron. These far-IR photometry provides the full IR SEDs and IR luminosity measurements. To crudely estimate the expected CO fluxes, we adopt one assumption: L(fir0)-L'(CO) relation for local ULIRGs (Solomon + van den Boute 2005), Log10[L(fir)] = 1.7*Log10[L'(CO)]-5.0. This relation gives less bright and more conservative estimates of CO fluxes than if assuming a local spiral galaxy relation of Log10[L(fir)] = 1.31*Log10[L'(CO)-1.37 (Daddi et al. 2010). We will use TDM (Time Division Mode) because our targets can be observed with low resolution wideband continuum observations. Dual polarizations are adopted. Assuming blackbody distributions, we can estimate 1mm and 3mm continua fluxes from observed Herschel photometry. The estimated continuum fluxes are in the range of (0.24-3)mJy at 1mm and (10-77)$\mu$Jy at 3mm. We expect we should be able to detect these continuum values from our data. None detections of continuum will set the minimum constraints on the far-IR SEDs.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We request 6.8 hrs to obtain CO J2-1 & J4-3 spectroscopy of 9 galaxies at z~1 in the CDFS. Our targets are selected to be both on and above the SFR-mass relation for star forming galaxies and have luminosities of L* galaxies at z~1. The uniqueness of this sample is its deepest Spitzer spectra, revealing that PAH strength is correlated the locations of galaxies on SFR-Mass plane. Our targets also have 3D Halpha spectra from VLT and HST. The ALMA spectra will complete this unique dataset with spatial and kinematic information for ionized gas, molecular gas and stars. The ALMA data will enable the following: (1) Determine if molecular gas properties are different for galaxies on and above SFR-Mass main sequence relation. We will test the hypothsis that higher molecular gas density is the driver for the SFR-Mass relation. (2) Measure the sizes and spatial distributions of CO and ionized Halpha gas, and study star formation law at z~1. Spatially resolved CO maps will set limits on the sizes of colder J1-0 gas, and the limits on gas surface densities. (3) Investigate the physical conditions of CO gas, such as excitation, temperature and number density using J2-1 and J4-3 line ratios.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:keyword: Luminous and Ultra-Luminous Infra-Red Galaxies (LIRG & ULIRG)

prp:PrincipalInvestigator.prp:organisation: Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: Dept of Physics & Astronomy, Tufts University
Faculty of Exact Sciences , Tel Aviv University
Institut d'Astrophysique Spatiale - IAS, Paris-Sud University
North American ALMA Science Center, National Radio Astronomy Observatory
Infrared Processing and Analysis Center (IPAC), California Institute of Technology
